Description: Egyptian lamp in the form of an African's head, with a filling-hole pierced through the crown. The hair is indicated by raised points with central depressions. The nozzle is mainly missing. Plastic lamp made in plaster mould.. The mould-made three-ridged ring handle has three transverse grooves, and the oval base-ring is flat within. The upper side is covered in a red slip. Brown Nile silt fabric with abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Similar handle to lamps Q571 and Q576 and similar style to lamp Q578 (Bailey 1975: 268). All three parallels are of 1st century BC Egyptian production and acquired in Egypt, presently in the British Museum (BM GR 1925,1120.60, 1966,1213.15, 1966,0216.76). Fabric is identical to figures made in Naukratis suggesting local production, if not from Naukratis then this is from somewhere in the Nile Delta region.
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q580)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 41, pl. XV, no. 12)
Walters 1914 / Catalogue of Greek and Roman Lamps in the British Museum (411)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.068) (Phase 1)
Acquisition notes: Purchased from sebakhin by Petrie during his 1884-1885 season.
